question: Born in Crete, this influential painter moved to Spain, where he became highly sought-after for his religious works. His paintings are characterized by elongated figures, dramatic lighting, and an intense spirituality that reflects the religious fervor of his time. Name this artist that was nicknamed for his nationality and is considered a significant figure in the Spanish Renaissance.

This city is where Ralph Ellison's Invisible Man works at the Liberty Paint Company. George Selden wrote about a cricket in one of this city's major public spaces. The Great Gatsby takes place in this city where Percy Jackson visits the Metropolitan Museum of Art. This city is where Stuart Little races boats in Central Park. Name this city in which the Harlem Renaissance took place.

pH in this fluid is regulated by the bicarbonate ion buffer system. Cells in this fluid include leukocytes and erythrocytes, while platelets help form clots that stop its flow. It is carried in arteries and veins. Name this fluid that delivers oxygen and nutrients to cells and is pumped by the heart.

Starburst types of these systems have unusually high supplies of gas, and they can combine in a process known as cannibalism. The "tuning fork diagram" is a graphic depiction of the Hubble classification scheme for these systems, which divides them into irregular, elliptical and spiral types. M31 is the Andromeda one. Name these regions of the universe that include the Milky Way.

This country was officially recognized in the Lateran Treaties of 1929. It has extraterritorial authority over Castel Gandolfo. Places of interest in this country include the Sistine Chapel and Saint Peter's Square and Basilica. Voting in this country is restricted to Cardinals under eighty years old. Name this world's smallest country located entirely within the city of Rome.

An American writer known for his macabre and mysterious stories, his haunting prose and explorations of themes like madness and guilt established him as a master of Gothic literature. Name this author who gained recognition with his poem 'The Raven'.

This poet delivered "The Gift Outright" at President John F. Kennedy's inauguration. One of his poems observes that "good fences make good neighbors" and is called "Mending Wall." His poem "Nothing Gold Can Stay" notes that "Nature's first green is gold." Name this poet who stated in his most famous poem that he took "the road less traveled by, and that has made all the difference."

This figure met his demise when he was struck by a piece of wood from his own vessel. While in Colchis visiting King Aeetes, he accomplished such tasks as yoking fire-breathing oxen and dispatching a group of warriors that sprang forth after dragon teeth were sown into the ground, all to get the Golden Fleece. He was aided in these tasks by his future wife Medea. Name this leader of the Argonauts.

This video game series is set in a post-apocalyptic world that features a retro-futuristic setting influenced by the post-war culture of 1950s America, imagining an alternate history where the transistor was never invented. Known for its open-world gameplay, it allows players to explore vast wastelands and make choices that affect the game's story and environment. Developed by Bethesda Game Studios and recently adapted into a TV show, what is the name of this RPG series that begins with the aftermath of a global nuclear war?

This treaty's Article 231, known as the "War Guilt Clause," assigned full blame for the war and all damages to Germany and its allies. It not only demanded reparations and territory from Germany but also mandated the disarmament of the German military and limited the size of the German navy. Additionally, it led to the creation of new nations in Eastern Europe and the League of Nations. What is the name of this treaty, that was signed in the Hall of Mirrors in a palace and ended World War I?

Before basketball, this athlete was a competitive swimmer, aiming to compete in the Olympics. Known for his calm demeanor and fundamental playing style, he earned the nickname "The Big Fundamental." He played his entire 19-season NBA career with the San Antonio Spurs, winning five NBA championships and two MVP awards. Who is this legendary power forward, celebrated for his leadership and consistency on the court?

This famous American traitor started his military career as a pharmacist and bookseller. He initially became a hero in the early stages of the American Revolutionary War by playing a key role in the capture of Fort Ticonderoga and was pivotal in the Battle of Saratoga. However, his name became synonymous with treason after his plot to surrender West Point to the British was exposed. He later served as a brigadier general in the British Army. Who is this controversial figure in American history?

This series is noted for its complex characters and storylines, as well as its frequent use of shocking plot twists, including the infamous "Red Wedding" episode. It is based on the book series "A Song of Ice and Fire" by George R.R. Martin, who served as a producer on the show. The show's extensive filming locations included Northern Ireland, Croatia, Iceland, and Spain. It set a record for the most Emmy Awards won by a scripted television series. What is the name of this fantasy television series that follows the power struggles among the Seven Kingdoms of Westeros?

This vast desert is not only composed of sand dunes; it also features mountains, rock plateaus, and extensive gravel plains. It is home to the desert ant, Cataglyphis bicolor, known for its unique ability to withstand extreme temperatures by sprinting across the sand. Despite its arid climate, it houses over 20 lakes, most of which are saltwater lakes. Covering most of North Africa, it is nearly as large as the United States. What is the name of this desert, the largest hot desert in the world?

Formulated in 1925, this equation is a key foundation of quantum mechanics and provides a mathematical description of the wave-like behavior of particles at atomic and subatomic scales. Unlike classical mechanics, it uses a wave function to describe probabilistically the state of a particle rather than determining precise outcomes. Developed by an Austrian physicist who later won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1933 for his contributions to the wave theory of matter, this equation has revolutionized our understanding of the atomic world. What is the name of this critical equation in quantum physics?

This ancient epic is traditionally attributed to a poet who is also credited with composing another foundational work of ancient Greek literature that details a famous war. The narrative centers on the protagonist's challenging journey home following the fall of Troy, which takes an arduous ten years to complete. Throughout his voyage, he encounters various mythical creatures including the Cyclops, the seductive Sirens, and the shape-shifting witch-goddess Circe. This epic is not just a tale of adventure but also explores themes of heroism, loyalty, and the human condition. What is the name of this seminal work, a cornerstone of ancient Greek literature, detailing the adventures of Odysseus?

Before entering politics, this future president briefly ran a general store and served as a Captain for the Illinois Miltia during the Black Hawk War. Despite his iconic image, he is the only president to hold a patent for an invention. His stovepipe hat was a practical accessory meant to hold important documents and letters. Name this president known for his leadership during the Civil War.

This Major League Baseball team was originally founded in Baltimore, Maryland, in 1901 before moving to New York City in 1903. Known for their distinctive pinstripe uniforms, they are often referred to by their nickname, "The Bronx Bombers." The team holds the record for the most MLB championships, having won 27 World Series titles. Their storied rivalries, especially with the Boston Red Sox, are among the most famous in baseball history. What is the name of this iconic baseball team, synonymous with success and a global fanbase?

This play is set in the Kingdom of Denmark and features a plot that revolves around themes of treachery, revenge, incest, and moral corruption. The protagonist of the play studies in Wittenberg and is visited by the ghost of his father, who reveals the truth about his murder. Famous for its exploration of the human psyche, it introduces phrases like "To be, or not to be" into the English lexicon. Name this tragedy, often considered William Shakespeare's masterpiece, which centers on the Prince of Denmark.

Launched into low Earth orbit in 1990, this space-based observatory has become one of the most important instruments in the history of astronomy. It was not the first space telescope, but it is one of the largest and most versatile, known for its deep field images that have provided a deeper look into space and time. This telescope is named after an American astronomer who is famous for his discovery of the universe's expansion. What is the name of this telescope that has allowed astronomers to observe the most distant stars and galaxies ever seen

This ancient trade route played a critical role in the spread of Buddhism from India to East Asia. It was established during the Han Dynasty around 130 B.C, and famous travelers like Marco Polo and Ibn Battuta traversed the route, documenting their journeys. Name this historic trade route which connected China with the Mediterranean.

This peak experiences geological uplift, growing approximately 4 mm every year. Its "death zone" above 8,000 meters is notorious for its harsh conditions, where the thin air contains insufficient oxygen to sustain human life for extended periods, contributing to the peril many climbers face. Successfully ascended for the first time by Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay in 1953, this mountain is renowned globally. What is the name of this mountain, known as the highest point on Earth?

This actress made her stage debut in the play "The Playboy of Seville" in 1971. She is known for her ability to master almost any accent, from a British accent in "The Iron Lady" to a Polish one in "Sophie's Choice." She holds the record for the most Academy Award nominations of any actor. Known for her roles in diverse films from "Kramer vs. Kramer" to "The Devil Wears Prada," who is this acclaimed actress often described as the "best actress of her generation"?

This golf tournament is the only major that does not rotate between courses, being held annually at the same location since its inception in 1934. It is known for its green jacket, which is awarded to the champion and must be returned to the clubhouse after a year. The event was won by Scottie Scheffler in 2024 and 2022 which Jon Rahm winning in between. Held in Augusta, Georgia, what is the name of this prestigious golf tournament, one of the four major championships in professional golf?

This American virologist was born in New York City in 1914. After focusing on influenza research, he shifted his attention to a viral disease that caused widespread fear and paralysis, particularly affecting children. In a significant act of public service, he chose not to patent his greatest medical discovery, famously stating, "Could you patent the sun?" His research led to the first effective vaccine against polio, introduced in 1955. What is the name of this influential medical researcher?

This international competition features a trophy made of 18-carat gold and weighs approximately 6 kilograms. The inaugural tournament was held in 1930, hosted by Uruguay, who also won the title. It is the most watched sporting event globally, surpassing even the Olympic Games in viewership. Held every four years, teams from around the world compete, but only Brazil has won five times, the most by any country. What is the name of this prestigious international football tournament?

This ruler of the Mali Empire during the early 14th century is celebrated not only for his wealth but also for his contributions to the spread of Islam in West Africa. He embarked on a famous pilgrimage to Mecca in 1324, which included a procession of thousands of attendants and camels laden with gold. His journey through Cairo was notably extravagant, causing a temporary devaluation of gold in the region due to his generous distributions. Under his reign, the legendary city of Timbuktu flourished as a center of trade and Islamic scholarship, marked by the construction of the Djinguereber Mosque. Who is this emperor, often cited as one of the wealthiest people in history?

This marine structure is large enough to be visible from space, comprising over 2,900 individual reefs and 900 islands. It hosts a significant population of dugongs and is one of the most biodiverse ecosystems on the planet. The reef is a breeding area for humpback whales migrating from the Antarctic. Located off the coast of Queensland in northeastern Australia, it is the world's largest coral reef system. What is the name of this UNESCO World Heritage Site known for its vibrant marine life?

This artist served in the First Regiment of African Light Cavalry in Algeria for two years. He suffered from cataracts in his later years, which greatly influenced his shift to broader brushstrokes and bolder color choices in his paintings. He is known for his detailed garden at Giverny, which he transformed into a living canvas and used as inspiration for many works. His series on water lilies and scenes of the French countryside are celebrated globally. Name this French painter, a founding father of Impressionism.

Constructed between 1792 and 1800, this iconic building was designed by Irish-born architect James Hoban. It has 132 rooms, 35 bathrooms, and 6 levels in the residence. It was rebuilt after being burned down during the War of 1812 in an event known as the Burning of Washington. Its first resident was President John Adams. What is this famous building called?

This novel intricately portrays the clash of cultures between feudal Japan and the Western world during the early 17th century. It is based on the historical adventures of an English navigator who becomes a samurai and political player within the Japanese feudal system. Published in 1975, it became a bestseller and was later adapted into a successful television miniseries in 1980 and again in 2024. What is the name of this historical novel by James Clavell that explores the rise of a foreigner in the Japanese samurai-led society?

This actor began his career with appearances in television commercials before moving on to recurring roles in TV series such as "Growing Pains." He is a committed environmentalist, founding a non-profit organization focused on global warming and preserving Earth's biodiversity. He received critical acclaim for his performance in "What's Eating Gilbert Grape" at a young age. Known for his collaborations with director Martin Scorsese in films like "The Wolf of Wall Street" and "Shutter Island," who is this Oscar-winning actor famous for his role in "Titanic"?

Constructed over several dynasties, this extensive fortification stretches more than 13,000 miles and was primarily built using tamped earth and later enhanced with brick and stone. Its construction began as early as the 7th century BC, with significant extensions during the Ming Dynasty. Originally designed to protect against nomadic invasions, it also controlled immigration and facilitated duties on goods transported along the Silk Road. What is this historical landmark?

Initially derived from the pancreases of dogs and later from cattle and pigs, this hormone plays a critical role in part of the body's metabolic regulation. Its first use in treating a human patient was in 1922. This medical advancement earned the discovering scientist the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1923. Today, it is synthesized using recombinant DNA technology, providing essential treatment for diabetes patients worldwide. What is this life-saving hormone called?

This ancient lake contains over 20% of the world's unfrozen freshwater reserve. It earned the nickname "Galápagos of Russia" due to its unique biodiversity. It is home to the world's only freshwater seal species. This UNESCO World Heritage Site boasts an exceptional array of endemic species. Located in southern Siberia, it is the world's deepest lake. What is the name of this lake, often referred to as the 'Pearl of Siberia'?

Before his infamous legal battles, this individual had a successful career in advertising, notably appearing in commercials for the Hertz rental car company. He set records in the NFL, including rushing over 2,000 yards in a single season, a feat achieved during a 14-game season. His transition to film and television included roles in movies and the popular "Naked Gun" series. In 1994, he was tried and acquitted in a highly publicized and controversial criminal trial for the murders of his ex-wife Nicole Brown Simpson and her friend Ronald Goldman. Who is this infamous former NFL running back and actor who died in 2024?

This competition is one of the most grueling one-day sporting events in the world, combining three continuous and sequential endurance races. It starts with a 2.4-mile swim, followed by a 112-mile bicycle ride, and finishes with a marathon 26.2-mile run, raced in that order without a break. Originating in Hawaii in 1978 as a challenge among groups of athletes to see who was the fittest—swimmers, cyclists, or runners—it has grown into a global phenomenon. What is the name of this triathlon that tests the limits of human endurance?

This film features a famous scene with a severed horse's head, which was real and acquired from a dog food company. The hauntingly beautiful score for the film was composed by Nino Rota. It is based on a novel by Mario Puzo and portrays the powerful Italian-American crime family of Don Vito Corleone. The film launched the careers of several actors, including Al Pacino, who plays Michael Corleone. Directed by Francis Ford Coppola, what is the name of this iconic film that won the Academy Award for Best Picture in 1972?

This historic chapel's ceiling was originally painted blue and decorated with stars before being replaced by the artwork that is seen today. It serves as the site for the Papal conclave, where new popes are elected. Renowned for its Renaissance art, particularly the frescoes that cover the interior, it features works by several prominent artists of the period, including Botticelli, Perugino, and Michelangelo. Michelangelo's contributions include not only the ceiling but also the iconic "The Last Judgment" on the altar wall. What is the name of this chapel located in Vatican City, famous for its magnificent Renaissance art?

Before joining NASA, this astronaut flew 78 combat missions during the Korean War and tested high-speed aircraft, including the X-15. He was part of the Gemini 8 mission, achieving the first successful docking of two spacecraft in orbit. He later became the first person to walk on the moon, famously declaring, "That's one small step for [a] man, one giant leap for mankind." Who is this pioneering astronaut?

This painting was created during the artist's time at the Saint-Paul-de-Mausole asylum in Saint-Rémy-de-Provence, France, after he voluntarily admitted himself. It depicts the view from the east-facing window of his asylum room, though it was painted from memory during the day. Characterized by swirling clouds in a starry night and a bright crescent moon, its vibrant colors and emotional depth are a signature of the artist's turbulent state of mind. Currently housed in the Museum of Modern Art in New York City, this work is one of the most recognized paintings in the history of Western culture. Name this iconic 1889 painting by Vincent van Gogh.

This television series was pitched by its creator, Vince Gilligan, as a story where the protagonist transforms into the antagonist. It features a character named Saul Goodman, who was later the subject of a successful spin-off prequel series. Filmed primarily in Albuquerque, New Mexico, it uses the unique landscape as a backdrop to its intense narrative. The series centers on Walter White, a high school chemistry teacher turned methamphetamine manufacturer. What is the name of this critically acclaimed series that won multiple Emmy Awards for its lead actor, Bryan Cranston?

This South American river is home to the uniquely colored and intelligent pink river dolphin. It flows through the world's largest tropical rainforest, encompassing an area twice the size of India. Despite its vast length, it has no bridges due to its width and the dense forest surrounding much of its length. It is the second-longest river globally but discharges the largest volume of water, influencing the Atlantic Ocean up to 100 miles from its mouth. What is the name of this river?

Originally built between 1871 and 1888 to accommodate the growing staff of the White House, this French Second Empire-style building is located next to the West Wing. It was initially known as the State, War, and Navy Building, reflecting its original occupants. Since 2002, its name honor has honored the 34th U.S. President. What is the official name of this building where the Vice President has an office?

First isolated using simple adhesive tape, this material was discovered at the University of Manchester by Andre Geim and Konstantin Novoselov, who were later awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 2010 for their work. It is notable for being just one atom thick, making it one of the thinnest yet strongest materials ever tested.What is this two-dimensional material composed of a single layer of carbon atoms arranged in a honeycomb lattice?

This athlete has a successful fashion line and has also been involved in numerous off-court ventures, including voice acting in animated films. She won her first major championship at the U.S. Open in 1999, setting the stage for one of the most dominant careers in tennis. Known for her powerful playing style and strong serve, she has won 23 Grand Slam singles titles, the most by any player in the Open Era. Who is this iconic tennis player, often celebrated as one of the greatest athletes of all time?

This period saw the development of the printing press by Johannes Gutenberg, significantly impacting the accessibility of knowledge. Notably, it emphasized humanism, redefining the intellectual landscape of Europe.It heralded major advancements in arts, introducing techniques like perspective in painting, represented by masters such as Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo. Name this cultural phenomenon that began in 14th century Florence and was characterized by a revival of classical learning and wisdom, a shift that distanced Europe from the Middle Ages.

This country is home to one of the world's oldest continuous major civilizations, with historical and urban settlements dating back to 4000 BC. It was known as Persia until 1935 and has a significant role in the history of the silk road and international trade. The nation is also known for its substantial oil reserves, ranking as the world's fourth-largest holder of oil. It features a diverse landscape ranging from arid mountains to lush forests. What is the name of this country that launched an air attack at Israel after they destroyed it's embassy in Syria?

This historical figure was born an Archduchess of Austria before becoming the Queen of France through her marriage to Louis XVI. Known for her extravagant lifestyle amid France's financial crisis, she was a controversial queen, often misquoted in response to hearing that the French peasants had no bread. Her reputation, whether deserved or not, fueled populist rage that contributed to the climactic moments of the French Revolution. She met her end by guillotine in 1793 during the Reign of Terror. Who is this queen, often remembered for her dramatic downfall?

Developed by a French mathematician in the early 19th century, this mathematical transform is essential for analyzing the frequencies contained in a signal. It decomposes a function or a dataset into a spectrum of its sine and cosine components, enabling engineers and scientists to work with the frequency domain rather than time domain. This technique has wide-ranging applications, including image processing, signal analysis, and quantum physics. What is the name of this transformative analysis method, named after its inventor?

This Argentine footballer is known for his low center of gravity and dribbling skills. He began his professional career with FC Barcelona, where he spent over two decades, setting records for the most goals scored for a single club. Renowned for his precise left foot, he has won numerous Ballon d'Or awards, distinguishing him as one of the best players of his generation. In 2021, he made a high-profile transfer to Paris Saint-Germain. What is the name of this iconic soccer player, often cited as one of the greatest footballers of all time?

This iconic ballet, first performed in 1877 at the Bolshoi Theatre in Moscow, was initially met with criticism but has since become one of the most beloved ballets worldwide. Its music was composed by Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky, and the ballet's plot revolves around a princess turned into a swan by an evil sorcerer's curse. Known for its demanding choreography, particularly the role of the dual lead of Odette/Odile, this ballet is a staple in the classical repertoire. What is the name of this ballet which was made into a movie starring Natalie Portman?

This Canadian actor was born in Beirut, Lebanon, in 1964 and first gained major Hollywood attention for his performance in "Speed." Known for his range, he has appeared in everything from romantic comedies like "Something's Gotta Give" to supernatural thrillers like "Constantine." Off-screen, he is lauded for his humility and philanthropic efforts, particularly his contributions to cancer research and children’s hospitals. He is also celebrated for his role as Neo in the "Matrix" trilogy and as the titular character in the "John Wick" film series. What is the name of this versatile and well-respected actor?

This American politician from Louisiana, a member of the Republican Party, has served in the U.S. House of Representatives since 2017. He represents Louisiana's 4th congressional district, which includes the northwestern part of the state. Known for his strong conservative views, he has been a vocal advocate for constitutional conservatism, emphasizing fiscal responsibility, limited government, and traditional family values. In 2023, he was elected as the Speaker of the House, becoming one of the key figures in the national political landscape. What is the name of this politician who currently holds the position of Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives?

Flowing through more countries than any other river in the world, this major European waterway starts in the Black Forest mountains of western Germany and extends through Central and Eastern Europe to the Black Sea. It has been a vital conduit for cultural exchange among the diverse regions along its path, historically serving as a long-standing frontier of the Roman Empire. Today, it plays a crucial role in the regions’ commerce, environmental sustainability, and tourism. What is the name of this second-longest river in Europe, known for connecting ten countries?

This iconic national park, located in California's Sierra Nevada mountains, was established in 1890. It was created largely due to the advocacy of naturalist John Muir. It includes one of the tallest waterfalls in North America as well as giant, ancient sequoia trees, and spectacular granite cliffs. What is the name of this national park known for its stunning natural beauty?

Known for his extraordinary height for a sprinter, this Jamaican athlete revolutionized the science of sprinting, focusing heavily on his start technique and stride efficiency. He set the world record for the 100 meters, 200 meters, and 4x100 meters relay, and his iconic celebration pose has become synonymous with his name. Dominating three consecutive Olympic Games, he secured gold medals in all three sprint events at Beijing 2008, London 2012, and Rio 2016. What is the name of this athlete, often referred to as the fastest man alive?

Invented by Nikola Tesla in the late 19th century, this electrical resonant transformer circuit is used to produce high-voltage, low-current, high-frequency alternating-current electricity. Notable for creating impressive electrical arcs and being used in entertainment and educational displays, it was originally developed as part of Tesla's experiments with wireless lighting and electrical power distribution. What is the name of this device that exemplifies Tesla’s work in electrical engineering?

This 2010 science fiction film directed by Christopher Nolan features a skilled thief who can enter people's dreams to steal secrets from their subconscious. His greatest challenge involves a complex task where he must implant an idea into a CEO's mind through a layered dream sequence. Known for its elaborate visual effects and a plot that weaves through various levels of consciousness, the film is also famous for its open-ended conclusion, symbolized by a spinning top. What is the name of this critically acclaimed film that explores the concept of dream manipulation?

Founded in 1769, this Ivy League institution was originally established to educate Native Americans in Christian theology and the English way of life. This university was the first of an elite group of American universities to bring back a requirement for ACT or SAT scores after the COVID-19 pandemic. Name this Ivy League school located in Hanover, New Hampshire.

This document, originally issued in 1215, was a result of the political crisis between King John of England and a group of rebel barons within his kingdom. It was first drafted by the Archbishop of Canterbury to make peace between the unpopular King and the rebels. Over time, it has become a symbol of liberty and the rule of law, particularly noted for its role in shaping the legal system of the British constitutional monarchy. What is the name of this historic charter often credited as a foundational document for modern democracy?

This pivotal event was triggered by legislation passed in 1773 that aimed to rescue the financially struggling British East India Company. It involved a late-night act of rebellion where protestors, some disguised as Mohawk Indians, boarded three ships in a famous harbor. What is this event, famously associated with the phrase "No taxation without representation"?

This figure from Norse mythology is known for his cunning and deceptive nature, often causing as much trouble for the other gods as he resolves. A shape-shifter capable of changing both form and gender, he plays a pivotal role in many myths, including the events leading up to Ragnarok, the end of the world in Norse legend. His complex character has inspired various modern portrayals, including a popular supervillain in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Known as the Norse god of mischief, what is his name?

Holding about 90% of the world’s ice and 70% of its fresh water, this continent is crucial for global climate regulation. Governed by an international treaty that designates it as a scientific preserve and prohibits military activity, it has no indigenous human population and supports only temporary research communities. The extreme environment, featuring the coldest temperatures recorded on Earth, facilitates studies ranging from glaciology to climate science. What is the name of this continent, renowned for its expansive ice sheets and unique legal status?

The first successful use of this invention was achieved in 1903 in Kitty Hawk, North Carolina. The initial use lasted only 12 seconds but covered 120 feet. Today, it is integral to global transportation and commerce. This invention revolutionized travel and military strategy, leading to the first nonstop transatlantic flight in 1919. What is this device which was invented by the Wright Brothers?

Developed in the early 21st century, this groundbreaking biotechnological tool allows for precise editing of the DNA in the genomes of living organisms. It utilizes a component of a bacterial immune system, which captures pieces of DNA from viruses, to make precise cuts in specific DNA sequences. This innovation has transformed genetic research, offering potential treatments for a myriad of genetic diseases and advancements in agricultural science. What is the name of this powerful gene-editing technology?

Originating in Asia and spreading via the Silk Road, this pandemic reached Europe in the mid-14th century, causing massive social upheaval and labor shortages due to its high mortality rate. The pathogen was transmitted by fleas carried on black rats aboard trading ships, leading to rapid spread through congested urban areas. Characterized by painful swellings called buboes, this devastating outbreak is known as one of the deadliest pandemics in human history. What is this historical epidemic commonly called?

In the arid regions surrounding this hypersaline lake, ancient manuscripts that include some of the earliest known religious texts were discovered, offering significant insights into early religious practices. Located at the lowest land elevation on Earth, this body of water allows swimmers to float effortlessly due to its extremely high salinity, which also supports a thriving health and cosmetics industry based on its mineral-rich mud. Bordered by Jordan to the east and Israel and the West Bank to the west, what is the name of this unique lake renowned for its buoyancy and therapeutic properties?

This prestigious tennis tournament, known for its unique tradition of consuming strawberries and cream by spectators, maintains a strict no-play policy on the middle Sunday to allow the grass courts to rest. Established in 1877, it is the oldest tennis tournament in the world and is particularly noted for its requirement that players wear all-white attire. Celebrated for being played on outdoor grass courts, this event is one of the four Grand Slam tournaments held annually. What is the name of this tournament, regarded as the most prestigious in the sport of tennis?

Launched in 2016, this Netflix original series combines 1980s nostalgia with supernatural and horror elements. Set in the fictional town of Hawkins, Indiana, the story begins with the mysterious disappearance of a young boy, which leads to revelations about secret government experiments and a girl with psychokinetic abilities. Created by the Duffer Brothers, this series has become a cultural phenomenon. What is the name of this show?

This U.S. government agency is responsible for tax collection and tax law enforcement. It administers the Internal Revenue Code enacted by Congress. Established in 1862 during the presidency of Abraham Lincoln, its primary purpose was to fund the Civil War. The agency is also known for its role in the annual observance of April 15th as Tax Day, the deadline for filing individual tax returns. In recent years, it has implemented various modernization efforts to improve taxpayer service and compliance. What is the name of this agency tasked with ensuring the nation's tax laws are followed?

This British author began his career as a political journalist before achieving fame with serialized novels that highlighted the social and economic challenges of Victorian England. Notable for exploring themes like poverty, child labor, and social injustice, his vivid characters and detailed settings have made works such as "Oliver Twist," "David Copperfield," and "A Christmas Carol" enduring classics. Name this author whose works have been adapted into numerous plays and films, continuing to influence popular culture.

Scheduled to be the third time this city has hosted the Summer Olympics, the 2024 event plans to integrate iconic landmarks as backdrops for competitions. This edition of the Games will also introduce breakdancing as an official Olympic sport. What is the host nation for the olympics which will feature beach volleyball at the foot of the Eiffel Tower and fencing at the Grand Palais?

This American basketball legend is renowned for his six NBA championships with the Chicago Bulls and two Olympic gold medals. Known for his scoring ability, defensive skills, and clutch performances, he won five MVP awards and is often regarded as the greatest basketball player of all time. What is the name of this iconic athlete, also famous for his global brand and "Air Jordan" sneakers?

This public health concept occurs when a sufficient proportion of a population becomes immune to an infectious disease, either through vaccination or previous infections, thus providing indirect protection to those who are not immune. It helps control the spread of contagious diseases and is crucial for protecting vulnerable individuals who cannot be vaccinated. What is the term used to describe this phenomenon, which plays a key role in preventing outbreaks and achieving disease control?

Initiated as a military project during the Cold War, this early computer network was developed by the Advanced Research Projects Agency. The first message sent on this network was supposed to be "LOGIN" but famously crashed after the first two letters. This network employed packet switching and was a precursor to the modern Internet. What is the name of this groundbreaking project that fundamentally changed the way information is disseminated and communicated globally?

This famous mural painting by an Italian Renaissance artist depicts Jesus Christ's final meal with his apostles before his crucifixion, as described in the Gospel of John. Notable for its detailed representation of the apostles' reactions and the use of perspective, it is located in the Convent of Santa Maria delle Grazie in Milan. What is the name of this masterpiece, created by Leonardo da Vinci?

This monarch, born in 1819, was known for her strict standards of personal morality and a lengthy reign that saw the expansion of the British Empire. Her era is often associated with the height of the Industrial Revolution. She was the granddaughter of King George III and the mother of nine children. Name this queen, whose name defines an entire age of British history.

This 1977 album by a British-American rock band is one of the best-selling albums of all time, noted for its production quality and harmonious sound despite the band members' tumultuous relationships at the time. Hits like "Go Your Own Way," "Dreams," and "The Chain" have made it a classic. What is the name of this Fleetwood Mac album, which was largely influenced by personal strife among band members?

This tropical paradise is made up of 26 atolls in the Indian Ocean, comprising over 1,000 coral islands. Known for its beaches, blue lagoons, and extensive reefs, the country is also the lowest-lying nation in the world, with an average ground level of just 1.5 meters above sea level. It gained independence from British protection in 1965. What is the name of this island nation, renowned for its vibrant marine life and luxury resorts?

This European mountain range features the Great St Bernard Pass, a historical route used since Roman times, and is renowned for its extensive ski resorts and hiking trails. Stretching approximately 1,200 kilometers across eight countries including France, Switzerland, Italy, and Austria. The range includes Mont Blanc, the highest peak at 4,809 meters. What is the name of this prominent mountain range known for its scenic beauty and outdoor recreational opportunities?

This poem, first published in 1845, is known for its melodic and dramatic qualities, exploring themes of despair, longing, and the torment of loss. The narrative follows a grieving man who encounters a mysterious raven, whose repeated word "Nevermore" enhances the poem's atmosphere of melancholy and doom. Written by an American writer famous for his tales and poems of horror and mystery, what is the name of this poem by Edgar Allan Poe?

This device, first successfully demonstrated in 1876, transformed global communication. Its early versions transmitted sound over a single wire, often requiring operators to connect calls. The inventor originally considered it an improvement to the telegraph. What device was famously first used by Alexander Graham Bell to summin his assistant with the words, "Mr. Watson, come here, I want to see you"?

This type of vaccine uses a synthetic strand of genetic material called messenger RNA to instruct cells in the body to produce a protein similar to one found in a virus. This protein triggers an immune response, preparing the body to fight the actual virus if encountered. First widely used during the COVID-19 pandemic, what is this innovative category of vaccines called?

Founded by a Roman Emperor in 330 AD, this city served as a capital for the Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman empires. Renowned for its strategic position between Europe and Asia, it was pivotal in controlling the passage between the Black Sea and the Mediterranean. The city fell to the Ottoman Empire in 1453, an event that marked the end of the Byzantine Empire. It was later renamed Istanbul. Name this historically significant city that was once known as the "Queen of Cities."

This German Formula One driver is renowned for his seven World Championships, tying him with Lewis Hamilton for the most titles in the history of the sport. Known for his precision driving and competitiveness, he drove for teams like Benetton and Ferrari, where he helped build the latter into one of the most successful teams in F1 history. What is the name of this legendary driver, often celebrated as one of the greatest Formula One racers ever?

This iconic American television series, created by Rod Serling, premiered in 1959 and is renowned for its twist endings and moral lessons. The show blended elements of science fiction, horror, and fantasy to explore complex social and existential themes through standalone, often surreal narratives. What is the name of this groundbreaking anthology series?

This popular online puzzle game, created by software engineer Josh Wardle, quickly gained a massive following after its release in 2021. The game challenges players to guess a five-letter word within six attempts, using color-coded feedback to show correct letters and placements. Its simple yet engaging format led to its acquisition by The New York Times. What is the name of this daily word game that has become a global phenomenon?

This German composer and pianist was a crucial figure in the transition between the Classical and Romantic eras in Western music. His compositions include 9 symphonies, 5 piano concertos, and a significant number of sonatas, among them the famously emotive “Moonlight Sonata.” Despite his progressive hearing loss, he continued to compose some of his greatest works, which remain central to the music repertoire today. What is the name of this influential composer, known for his symphony “Ode to Joy”?

Established after World War I as part of the Treaty of Versailles in 1920, this international organization was intended to maintain world peace and prevent future conflicts. Despite its efforts, it struggled with membership and enforcement power, failing to stop aggression from Axis powers in the 1930s. It was eventually replaced by the United Nations after World War II. Name this precursor to the United Nations, which aimed to promote diplomatic dialogue and collective security.

This Swiss tennis player, renowned for his graceful play and sportsmanship, has won 20 Grand Slam singles titles, a record he held until surpassed by his rivals. Known for his prowess on grass courts, especially at Wimbledon where he has won a record eight times, he is celebrated as one of the greatest tennis players of all time. What is the name of this legendary tennis icon?

This computer launched in 1977 as one of the first to come with a color display and was sold as a fully assembled circuit board. It included a keyboard and was notably user-friendly, which helped it stand out in a market dominated by technical kits for hobbyists. Name this early PC that helped launch the personal computer revolution and solidified its company, founded by two Steves, as a key player in the technology sector.

These computational systems are inspired by the biological neural networks that constitute animal brains. Utilized in machine learning, they are composed of layers of interconnected nodes or "neurons" that can learn to recognize patterns and make decisions by adjusting the strength of the connections based on the data they process. What is the term for these powerful tools in artificial intelligence that mimic the structure and function of the human brain?

This American businessman and television personality turned politician was known for his real estate ventures and the reality TV show "The Apprentice" before entering the political arena. In 2016, he won the U.S. presidential election as the Republican candidate, becoming the 45th President of the United States. Noted for his unconventional approach to politics and governance, he is also the first president without prior military or government service. What is the name of this figure, who was impeached twice during his term?

This 1993 film, directed by Steven Spielberg, is noted for its poignant use of black and white cinematography, and it won seven Academy Awards, including Best Picture. It tells the story of a German businessman who saved over a thousand Polish-Jewish refugees during the Holocaust by employing them in his factories. What is the name of this powerful historical drama?

This mountain range extends over 7,000 kilometers and is known for its varied climates, from arid to one of the wettest places on Earth. It is home to many unique species and reaches its highest point at Mount Aconcagua, which is the highest peak outside Asia. Passing through seven countries, it is the longest continental mountain range located along the western coast of South America. What is the name of this significant mountain range?

This iconic statue representing a Roman goddess was designed by Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi and dedicated on October 28, 1886. It features a broken chain at its feet, symbolizing freedom and the abolition of slavery. The statue's exterior is made of copper sheets, which have oxidized to form its green patina. Initially, it served as a lighthouse, guiding ships into New York Harbor. What is this American landmark commonly known as?

This ancient civilization, known for its road systems, architectural achievements like the Colosseum, and influential legal structures, became one of the largest empires in history. It reached its peak under Emperor Trajan and eventually split into Western and Eastern segments. The empire began expanding from a city on the Italian Peninsula in the 8th century BC. Name this empire, famous for its vast influence across Europe.

This term describes the boundary around a black hole beyond which no radiation can escape. It shares its name with a 1997 sci-fi horror film that explores a spaceship encountering a similar boundary in space. The concept was first detailed by the German astronomer Karl Schwarzschild. What is this term, which marks the limits of a black hole's gravitational influence?

This American filmmaker directed iconic films across genres, including "2001: A Space Odyssey" and "The Shining." Known for his meticulous craftsmanship and thematic complexity, his works are celebrated for innovative cinematography and deep philosophical underpinnings. What is the name of this influential director whose style has left a lasting impact on the film industry?

This American golfer has won 15 major championships, including five Masters Tournaments. Famous for his red shirt on final-round Sundays and his influence in making golf a global sport, he is one of the most recognized and highest-earning athletes in the world. What is the name of this iconic golfer, often referred to simply by his first name?

Known for its two major tributaries with the names, Blue and White, this river traverses eleven countries, including Uganda, Sudan, and Egypt. It plays a vital role in agriculture, particularly for Egyptian civilizations since ancient times. Flowing northward through northeastern Africa and draining into the Mediterranean Sea, this is recognized as the longest river in the world. What is the name of this significant African river?

This novel, published in 1922 by an Irish author, is known for its stream of consciousness technique and deep exploration of the mundane activities of its characters during a single day in Dublin. The narrative parallels the structure of Homer’s epic, "The Odyssey," with its characters reflecting modern versions of those from the ancient text. What is the name of this complex and highly influential modernist work by James Joyce?

This region, located on the eastern coast of the Mediterranean Sea, has been a focal point of conflict between Israel and Hamas. The conflict in this region grew into a full war after terrorist attacks by Hamas in Israel on October 7, 2023. What is the name of this territory that has been at the center of protracted and intense geopolitical strife?

This series of approximately 250 oil paintings by a French Impressionist captures the artist's flower garden at his home in Giverny, with the main focus on a pond. Created during the last 30 years of his life, these paintings show the artist's shifting focus from representing the garden's landscape to the play of light and shadow across the pond's surface. What is the name of this series by Claude Monet, celebrated for its exploration of perception and natural beauty?

This pivotal event of World War II occurred on June 6, 1944. The planning of this operation was shrouded in secrecy, utilizing deception techniques such as fake equipment and phantom armies. It involved the largest amphibious invasion in history with the use of over 5,000 vessels and 13,000 aircraft and marked a turning point in the war against Nazi Germany. Originally codenamed Operation Overlord, what is this historic day commonly known as?

Released in 1995, this groundbreaking film was the first feature-length movie created entirely using computer-generated imagery (CGI). It tells the story of a group of toys that come to life when humans aren't looking, led by Woody the cowboy and Buzz Lightyear, a space ranger. This film set new standards in animation and launched a successful franchise. What is the name of this pioneering animated film produced by Pixar?

This NBA team has a storied history with 17 championships, tying them for the most in league history. Known for their purple and gold colors, they have been home to basketball legends such as Magic Johnson, Kobe Bryant, and LeBron James. What is the name of this iconic basketball franchise based in Los Angeles?

This Asian mountain range is known for containing many of the world's highest peaks, including over 100 that exceed 7,200 meters. It is home to the famous K2 and the highest point on Earth, Mount Everest. The range also forms a natural barrier between the Indian subcontinent and the Tibetan Plateau. What is the name of this extensive mountain range, crucial for its climatic impact and cultural significance in the regions it spans?

This port city in southeastern Ukraine became a focal point during the Russo-Ukrainian War. Heavily industrialized, it is strategically located on the coast of the Sea of Azov, linking it directly to the Black Sea. In 2022, the city endured a significant siege that resulted in widespread destruction and a humanitarian crisis, highlighting the severe impacts of the conflict. What is the name of this city which was subject of an Oscar-winning documentary in 2024?

First predicted by Albert Einstein's theory of general relativity in 1916, these ripples in spacetime are generated by some of the most violent and energetic processes in the Universe, such as colliding black holes or exploding stars. They were directly detected for the first time in 2015 by the LIGO observatory, confirming a major prediction of Einstein's theory. What are these disturbances in spacetime that share a name with an essential physical force called?

This decisive battle took place on June 18, 1815, near Brussels. It featured a coalition of armies led by the Duke of Wellington and a Prussian army under General Blücher, who faced Napoleon Bonaparte’s French troops, and marked the end of the Napoleonic Wars. The defeat led to Napoleon's abdication and exile to Saint Helena. Name this battle, often cited as one of the major turning points in European history.

Formed by volcanic activity, this archipelago consists of hundreds of islands spread over 1,500 miles in the central Pacific Ocean. It became the 50th U.S. state in 1959 and is known for its rich cultural heritage. The state's major islands include Oahu, Maui, Kauai, and the Big Island. What is the name of this U.S. state, celebrated for its natural beauty?

Founded by Osman I in the late 13th century, this empire expanded across three continents at its peak under Suleiman the Magnificent. Known for its military prowess and cultural synthesis, it significantly influenced Southeastern Europe, Western Asia, and Northern Africa. Name this empire, which had a capital of Constantinople and dissolved after World War I.

This British Formula One driver has matched the record for the most World Championships in the sport, with seven titles, sharing this achievement with Michael Schumacher. Known for his skillful driving and advocacy for social issues, he has raced predominantly for Mercedes-Benz and has set numerous records, including the most career wins. What is the name of this influential and successful Formula One racer?

This American politician served as a U.S. Senator from Delaware for 36 years before becoming Vice President under Barack Obama from 2009 to 2017. Known for his work on foreign relations, criminal justice, and domestic policy issues, he won the presidential election in 2020 to become the 46th President of the United States. What is the name of this President, notable for being the oldest person inaugurated to this office?

This American musical blends hip-hop, jazz, R&B, and Broadway styles to tell the story of a forgotten Founding Father. It was inspired by a 2004 biography and features a racially diverse cast to reflect America's contemporary composition rather than its historical one. The show's creator, who also originated the title role, earned widespread acclaim for his innovative approach to storytelling. What is the name of this groundbreaking musical that reimagines the life of Alexander Hamilton?

This day in U.S. history witnessed a brave act of passenger resistance aboard United Flight 93, which resulted in the plane crashing into a field in Pennsylvania, thwarting the hijackers' intended attack on the nation's capital. The aftermath of the attacks on this day saw significant changes in U.S. policy, including the establishment of the Department of Homeland Security and stricter aviation security measures. The same day, other hijacked planes struck the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. What is the date of these pivotal events known as in American history?

This popular American sitcom, which debuted in 1994, follows the lives of six friends living in New York City as they navigate the ups and downs of adulthood. Known for its witty dialogue, memorable one-liners, and iconic coffee shop setting, the show remained a top-rated TV show throughout its ten-season run. It has left a lasting impact on television comedy. What is the name of this beloved sitcom?

This graph, first plotted by scientist Charles David Keeling in 1958, shows the concentration of atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2) based on continuous measurements taken at the Mauna Loa Observatory in Hawaii. It is considered one of the most important scientific contributions to the understanding of global climate change because it provides clear evidence of rising CO2 levels over decades. What is this iconic graph that tracks the increasing presence of a key greenhouse gas in Earth's atmosphere called?

Revered as sacred by millions, particularly in Hinduism, this river supports one of the world’s highest population densities and is central to agriculture in both India and Bangladesh. Historically significant for centuries, it originates in the Indian Himalayas and flows over 2,525 kilometers into the Bay of Bengal. What is the name of this vital South Asian river?

Proposed by a British theoretical physicist in 1974, this theoretical prediction suggests that black holes are not entirely black but emit radiation due to quantum effects near the event horizon. This radiation implies that black holes can slowly lose mass and eventually evaporate over astronomical timescales. What is the name of this radiation, named after the scientist who first theorized its existence?

This Italian explorer, sailing under the Spanish flag, set out on his first voyage in 1492 with three ships: the Niña, the Pinta, and the Santa María. He is often mistakenly credited with being the first European to reach the Americas. His expeditions marked the beginning of European exploration and colonization of the American continents. Name this historical figure whose voyages had a profound impact on the global interactions of the Renaissance era.

This Japanese animated film, released in 2001, became critically acclaimed for its rich storytelling and animation. Directed by Hayao Miyazaki and produced by Studio Ghibli, it tells the story of a young girl navigating a world of spirits and gods after her parents are transformed into pigs. Name this film that won the Academy Award for Best Animated Feature, making it the first and only hand-drawn and non-English-language animated film to win the award.

This politician is the longest serving Senator from New York. Before he was elected to the senate he served nine terms in the House of Represenatives. He was the first Jewish Senate Majority Leader. Name this current Senate Majority Leader who has led the Democrats in the Senate since 2017.

This American golfer, known as "The Golden Bear," has won a record 18 major championships, a mark that stands as the benchmark for success in professional golf. Renowned for his powerful play and strategic approach, he won six Masters Tournaments and four U.S. Open titles among his impressive tally. What is the name of this legendary golfer, celebrated for his dominance in the sport's biggest tournaments?

Initially patented by Joseph Swan, this invention saw significant improvement when a more durable filament material was used by another inventor. It's often associated with a famous American inventor's first major public system of electric illumination. This innovation has evolved into various forms including LED and CFL. What is this invention which is often credited to Thomas Edison and commonly used to illuminate homes and streets?

This German composer of the Baroque period is renowned for his intricate compositions and profound influence on the structure of classical music. His works, characterized by their intellectual depth, technical command, and artistic beauty, include the "Brandenburg Concertos," "The Well-Tempered Clavier," and numerous cantatas and fugues. He spent much of his career as a church musician and a Kapellmeister in Leipzig. What is the name of this composer, celebrated for his masterful use of counterpoint and harmony?

This American singer was involved in a highly publicized incident during the Super Bowl XXXVIII halftime show in 2004, which resulted in a nationwide controversy. The performance concluded with a surprise "wardrobe malfunction" during a duet with Justin Timberlake, leading to immediate media backlash and changes in broadcast regulations. What is the name of this artist, whose performance led to the coining of the term "wardrobe malfunction"?

This fundamental concept in quantum mechanics, introduced by a German physicist in 1927, states that it is impossible to simultaneously know both the exact position and exact momentum of a particle. The more precisely one property is measured, the less precisely the other can be controlled or known. This principle challenged classical ideas of exactitude in science. Name the physicist who formulated this principle, which has profound implications for the behavior of subatomic particles.

This novel, published in 1925 by a prominent English writer, is set in post-World War I London and spans a single day in the life of its protagonist, who prepares for a party she will host that evening. The narrative delves into the complexities of its characters' thoughts and memories, utilizing the stream of consciousness technique to reveal their inner lives. What is the name of this seminal modernist work which follows Clarissa Dalloway by Virginia Woolf?

This national soccer team holds the record for the most FIFA World Cup victories, having won the prestigious tournament five times. Known for their skillful play and prominent players like Pelé and Ronaldo, they first won in 1958 and secured their latest title in 2002. What is the name of this country's team, celebrated for its rich football heritage and success on the global stage?

This city had over 10 inches of rain fall in a 24 hour period in April 2024. This set a record for the last 75 years in this city which lies in a desert nation known for its oil reserves. This city is also home to the world's tallest building, the Burj Khalifa. Name this city which was recently overwhelmed by flooding in the United Arab Emirates.

This geological marvel was first seen by European eyes in 1540, part of an expedition led by Spanish explorers. Despite its remote location, it became more accessible after the construction of a railway bearing its name 1901. This natural wonder was designated as a national park in 1919 by President Woodrow Wilson. What is the name of this famous canyon that was carved over millions of years by the Colorado River?

This mountain range stretches over 3,000 miles from British Columbia to New Mexico and includes Mount Elbert, its highest peak. Known for the Continental Divide, it forms the eastern portion of the North American Cordillera. This range shares a name with a baseball team based in Denver and has been invoked in beer commercials. What is the name of this iconic North American mountain range?

This transformative period began in Britain in the late 18th century and spread to other parts of the world. It was marked by the transition from hand production methods to machines, new chemical manufacturing and iron production processes, and the rise of the factory system. Notable innovations include the steam engine and spinning jenny. Name this era that dramatically changed economies, societies, and environments across the globe.

This groundbreaking music video, released in 1983 by an American pop star, revolutionized the music industry with its elaborate narrative and dance sequences. Directed by John Landis and featuring iconic zombie dance moves, the video extended over 13 minutes, blending music with cinematic storytelling. It became a global phenomenon and significantly boosted sales of the album of the same name. What is the name of this influential music video by Michael Jackson?

This thought experiment in quantum mechanics involves a hypothetical cat that may be simultaneously both alive and dead, depending on an earlier random event. Devised by an Austrian physicist in 1935, it illustrates the concept of superposition—the ability of a quantum system to be in multiple states at once until it is measured. Name the physicist who created this paradoxical experiment to challenge the Copenhagen interpretation of quantum mechanics.

This period of geopolitical tension between the Soviet Union and the United States spanned from 1947 to 1991. Characterized by the arms race, space competition, and various proxy wars, it never escalated into direct military conflict between the two superpowers. Notable events include the Cuban Missile Crisis and the fall of the Berlin Wall. Name this era marked by the struggle for global supremacy without open warfare.

This major North American river is known for its historical importance as a trade route during the era of steamboats. It flows over 2,300 miles from northern Minnesota to the Gulf of Mexico, making it the second-longest river in the United States. The river also passes through or borders ten states, including Illinois, Iowa, and Louisiana. What is the name of this river, vital for its ecological diversity and economic significance in U.S. history?

This iconic statue was sculpted by an Italian Renaissance artist between 1501 and 1504 and stands at over 14 feet tall. Originally commissioned as one of a series of statues for Florence Cathedral, it now resides in the Galleria dell'Accademia in Florence. Representing the Biblical hero who defeated Goliath, it is renowned for its detailed anatomy and expression of calm readiness. What is the name of this famous marble sculpture created by Michelangelo?

Known for his charismatic presence and phrases like "float like a butterfly, sting like a bee," this American boxer became a cultural icon beyond the world of sports. He won the world heavyweight championship three times and participated in several historic boxing matches, including the "Rumble in the Jungle." His refusal to serve in the Vietnam War due to his religious beliefs and stance on civil rights brought him significant attention and controversy. What is the name of this legendary boxer, often referred to as "The Greatest"?

This U.S. state, known for its desert climate and picturesque landscapes was admitted to the union in 1912 as the 48th state. This state's Supreme Court recently paved the wave for enforcement of a strict abortion restriction which was passed into law during the U.S. Civil War. What is the name of this southwestern state, recognized for its unique cacti and significant Native American history?

This individual won a Grammy Award for his audiobook "Dreams from My Father" and taught constitutional law at the University of Chicago Law School.He was the first African American president of the Harvard Law Review in 1990. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2009. Can you name this prominent political figure?

This women's rights advocate and social reformer was arrested and fined for illegally attempting to vote in the 1872 presidential election.  She was once depicted on a dollar coin issued by the U.S. Treasury, though it failed to gain widespread circulation. She co-founded the National Woman Suffrage Association with Elizabeth Cady Stanton. Name this tireless champion of women's rights

This dormant volcano in Tanzania is known for its three volcanic cones: Kibo, Mawenzi, and Shira. Popular among climbers and trekkers worldwide, it features a snow-capped summit near the equator, despite being located just 205 miles from the equator. Rising about 5,895 meters (19,341 feet) above sea level, it holds the title of the highest mountain in Africa. What is the name of this mountain, a symbol of towering natural beauty and challenge?

This American director, known for his dynamic storytelling and strong character development, has a long-standing collaboration with actor Robert De Niro, with whom he created classics like "Taxi Driver" and "Raging Bull." His films often explore complex themes such as crime, guilt, and redemption. Among his celebrated works is "Goodfellas," a critical and commercial success that redefined the gangster genre. What is the name of this influential filmmaker?

This American swimmer set the record for the most Olympic medals won by any athlete, totaling 28 medals, including 23 golds. His performances at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, where he won eight gold medals, are particularly celebrated. Who is this legendary swimmer who featured in a series of Subway ads?

This musical, based on a French novel of the same name by Gaston Leroux, is renowned for its captivating romance and haunting narrative. It tells the story of a disfigured musical genius, who haunts the Parisian entertainment venue and becomes obsessed with a young soprano, Christine. Composed by Andrew Lloyd Webber, it is one of the longest-running shows on Broadway. What is the name of this iconic musical?

This leader implemented the Yassa code to promote trade and communication within his empire, which stretched from Eastern Europe across Asia to the Sea of Japan. He united the nomadic tribes of Northeast Asia, founding the largest contiguous empire in history. His conquests encompassed large parts of Central Asia and China, with his descendants continuing to expand the empire after his death. Name this Mongolian ruler, born in the late 12th century.

This American politician served as the Attorney General of California and then as a United States Senator before making history in her current role. She became the first female Vice President of the United States in January 2021, also making her the highest-ranking female official in U.S. history, and the first African American and South Asian American to hold this office. What is the name of this groundbreaking political figure?

Developed to combat vitamin A deficiency, this genetically modified crop produces beta-carotene in its grain, which the human body can convert into vitamin A. This innovation is especially aimed at improving the health outcomes in developing countries where rice is a staple food but malnutrition is prevalent. What is the colorful name of this biofortified rice that has been altered to address a specific nutritional deficiency?

Known locally as 'Mosi-oa-Tunya,' which translates to 'The Smoke That Thunders,' this natural wonder creates a thunderous roar and a mist that can be seen from miles away. It forms one of the largest curtains of falling water in the world, drawing visitors from all over the globe to its breathtaking views. Designated as a UNESCO World Heritage site, it straddles the border between Zambia and Zimbabwe along the Zambezi River. What is the name of this magnificent waterfall, celebrated as one of the Seven Natural Wonders of the World?

Launched in 1588 by King Philip II of Spain, this fleet was one of the largest maritime fleets in European history, consisting of 130 ships manned by 8,000 sailors and over 18,000 soldiers. Its mission was to overthrow Queen Elizabeth I of England and halt the influence of Protestantism in Europe. Despite its formidable size, the fleet suffered a disastrous defeat due to a combination of strategic miscalculations, stormy weather, and effective tactics by the English navy. What is this famous naval campaign commonly known as, which marked a pivotal moment in Anglo-Spanish relations?

This novel intricately portrays the clash of cultures between feudal Japan and the Western world during the early 17th century. It is based on the historical adventures of an English navigator who becomes a samurai and political player within the Japanese feudal system. Published in 1975, it became a bestseller and was later adapted into a successful television miniseries in 1980 and again in 2024. What is the name of this historical novel by James Clavell that explores the rise of a foreigner in the Japanese samurai-led society?

This scientist was born in 1822 in a region now part of the Czech Republic and initially entered a monastery where he could receive an education. He conducted hybridization experiments in the monastery's garden, using pea plants to study inheritance patterns. His work laid the foundation for the modern understanding of genetics, though it was largely ignored during his lifetime. What is the name of this pioneer of genetic research, known for his laws of inheritance?

Before becoming president, this man owned a whiskey distillery, one of the largest in the nation. From 1749 to 1750, he served in his first public office as surveyor of Culpeper County in the Colony of Virginia. This Founding Father led the Continental Army in battle against the British during the Revolutionary War. Name this general and first president of the United States.

Published in 1925, this iconic American novel captures the spirit of the Roaring Twenties with its themes of decadence, idealism, and the pursuit of the American Dream. Narrated by Nick Carraway, the story delves into the lives of the wealthy occupants of Long Island's North Shore, focusing on his mysterious and affluent neighbor's quest to reunite with a former lover. Celebrated for its sharp critique of social stratification and the elusive nature of happiness, this novel remains a staple of American literature. What is the title of this F. Scott Fitzgerald work, emblematic of the Jazz Age?

This British singer-songwriter rose to fame with her debut album "19," and further captivated audiences worldwide with her soulful voice in the follow-up album "21," which included hits like "Rolling in the Deep" and "Someone Like You." Known for her deep, expressive vocals and poignant lyrics, her music often explores themes of love, heartbreak, and self-reflection. Winning multiple Grammy Awards, she has become one of the best-selling music artists of the 21st century. What is the name of this influential artist whose third album, "25," continued her streak of chart-topping success?

This annual event, established in 1897, is the world's oldest annual marathon and ranks as one of the world's most prestigious road racing events. It is held on Patriots' Day, the third Monday of April. The race starts in rural Hopkinton. Notably, it was the scene of a tragic event in 2013 when bombings near the finish line resulted in widespread injuries and loss of life. What is the name of this historic marathon known for its challenging course and storied history?
